Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Graphene Heterostructures Based Hot Carrier Optoelectronics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The objective of this proposal is to study the nonequilibrium hot carrier dynamics in graphene, and to explore novel graphene heterostructure devices for hot carrier optoelectronic applications. The approach is based on the integration of scanning photocurrent technique with femtosecond time-delay measurement technique. The proposal also aims to demonstrate a new type of graphene heterostructure based ultra-broadband infrared photodetector with high responsivity.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit is the pioneering of graphene based hot carrier optoelectronics. The femtosecond scanning photocurrent measurement technique can be applied to other optoelectronic devices, and the investigation of hot carrier dynamics in graphene should improve the fundamental understanding of optoelectronic physics in low dimension. The hot carrier tunneling mediated photoresponse in graphene heterostructure transistors will also lead to new photodetection mechanism ideal for mid-far infrared applications.

Broader Impacts: The proposed research is highly transformative and will generate a new type of room temperature broadband infrared detector with unparalleled sensitivity. The proposal?s strong emphasis on basic science, nanoscale material, and device physics will enhance science and engineering education at both undergraduate and graduate level. The proposed outreach activities will also promote the awareness and interest in nanoscience and nanotechnology for K-12 and undergraduate students. This program will place emphasis on recruiting students from underrepresented groups. Knowledge and technologies gain from this research will be incorporated into undergraduate course revision and the development of a new graduate course focusing on carbon nanomaterials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Graphene provides unique opportunities in optoelectronics due to the combination of high carrier mobility, 2.3% per layer flat band interaction with light over almost the whole spectrum range, and suitability for wafer-scale lithographic fabrication. Notably, the zero bandgap electronic structure of graphene enables optoelectronic applications in the mid-infrared, far-infrared and Terahertz (THz) frequency regions where conventional semiconductor devices are severely limited. Despite its potential, two main fundamental constrains need to be addressed for the development of graphene optoelectronics: 1) The physics related to the ultrafast dynamics of non-equilibrium hot carriers in photocurrent generation are not clear. 2) Despite the large absorption cross-section, single layer of graphene only absorbs 2.3% of light, fundamentally limiting the sensitivity and efficiency of graphene optoelectronic devices.

This research effort pioneered graphene based hot carrier optoelectronics. On the hot carrier physics, the research uncovered a novel lateral photo-Dember effect that is dominating the hot carrier dynamics at the graphene metal interface under ultrafast excitation. In addition, this work studied the microscopic origins of the terahertz carrier relaxation and cooling dynamics in graphene, and demonstrated, experimentally, that the cooling dynamics are dominated by the combined effect of efficient carrier–carrier scattering, which maintains a thermalized carrier distribution, and carrier–optical–phonon scattering, which removes energy from the carrier liquid. On the device front, this research pioneered a novel hot carrier tunneling assisted phototransistor based on double layer graphene heterostructure. This new detector offers room temperature high photoresponsivity across a broad spectrum range, from visible to mid infrared. Built on this finding, this research further demonstrated novel light-field photodetection and imaging based on the stacked transparent graphene photodetectors. In addition, concept of on-chip spectrometer is also demonstrated based on the gate tunability of the graphene detector.

The project also integrated a detailed outreach and education program, which promoted awareness of and interest in nanoscience and nanotechnology among K-12 and undergraduate students. The knowledge and research findings resulting from this project have been integrated into several new nanotechnology courses that are related to carbon nanotechnology, solid state and device physics. This project also helps to recruit and train undergraduate and graduate students and improves the diversity of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines and workforce.
